title: Double slit - fringe change for 1-3rd slit spacing

content.question: A laser beam is incident on two closely-spaced, parallel slits that are a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> apart. An interference pattern is then formed on a screen that is a distance <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> from the slits. Adjacent bright spots in the interference pattern are a distance <math alttext="delta s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi></math> apart, where <math alttext="delta s is much less than L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>≪</mo><mi>L</mi></math>. If the slits are replaced by different slits separated by a distance <math alttext="the fraction d over 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the new distance between adjacent bright spots in the resulting interference pattern formed on the same screen by the same laser?

choices.label: <math alttext="the fraction delta s over 9 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow><mn>9</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="the fraction delta s over 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="3 delta s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="9 delta s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>9</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="3 delta s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>s</mi></mstyle></math>
